steps.title: Get 2 different sized boxes.
steps.content: Get 2 different sized boxes. The boxes will be the molds that you’ll use to create the planters. Find 1 large box and a slightly smaller box. The smaller box should be able to fit inside of the larger box. The space in between the 2 boxes will determine the thickness of your concrete planters. [1] X Research source The boxes can be made of cardboard or wood. The smaller box should be at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) smaller than the big box on each side. The smaller box should be at least 8 inches (20 cm) deep for larger plants and 3–4 inches (7.6–10.2 cm) deep for smaller plants. Get sturdy boxes so that the mold doesn’t break when you fill it with concrete.

steps.title: Use plastic containers rather than boxes.
steps.content: Use plastic containers rather than boxes. If you want a concrete planter that’s a different shape than a rectangle or square, you can purchase plastic containers of any shape to serve as your molds. [2] X Expert Source Melinda Meservy Plant Specialist Expert Interview. 18 August 2020. Find 2 different sized plastic containers online or at a department store. The smaller container should be at least 2 inches (5.1 cm) smaller than the larger container around each side. The smaller container should be at least 8 inches (20 cm) deep for larger plants and 3–4 inches (7.6–10.2 cm) deep for smaller plants. For instance, you can get 2 pots or 2 plastic bowls.

steps.title: Tape a plastic trash bag around the smaller container.
steps.content: Tape a plastic trash bag around the smaller container. Stretch the trash bag over the smaller container so that it's taut against the sides. The trash bag should be tight against the inside of the container as well. Tape the trash bag to the box or container with duct tape. [3] X Research source The plastic bag will prevent the concrete from sticking to the small container and will make it easier to remove the mold.

steps.title: Mark 2 inches (5.1 cm) from the bottom of the large container.
steps.content: Mark 2 inches (5.1 cm) from the bottom of the large container. Use a ruler to measure 2 inches (5.1 cm) from the base on the inside of the large container. Make a horizontal line with a pen or marker. This will help you determine how much concrete you should initially pour into the mold. [4] X Research source If you want the sides of your planter to be thicker, measure and mark the line to reflect the change in dimensions. For instance, if your planter's walls are 4 in (10 cm)-thick, you'd measure and mark 4 inches (10 cm) from the base of the planter.

steps.title: Coat the inside of the larger box with cooking spray.
steps.content: Coat the inside of the larger box with cooking spray. Spread the non-stick spray around to get an even coating on the inside of the larger box. The cooking spray will make it so that the concrete doesn’t stick to the sides of the larger container. [5] X Research source You can purchase a can of cooking spray online or at a grocery store. You can coat the inside of the larger box with mineral spirits as an alternative to cooking spray. Pour the spirits into the bottom of the box and spread it around on the inside of the box with a rag.

steps.title: Mix concrete
steps.content: Mix concrete and water in a wheelbarrow or bucket. [6] X Expert Source Melinda Meservy Plant Specialist Expert Interview. 18 August 2020. Read all of the instructions on the package of concrete so you know the ratio of concrete to water. Put on a pair of gloves and pour the concrete mix into the wheelbarrow or bucket. Then, slowly pour in the appropriate amount of water into the concrete mix. Mix the concrete and water with a stick or shovel until it’s an oatmeal-like consistency. [7] X Research source You can add a variety of powdered concrete pigments during the mixing process to infuse different colors into the planter. [8] X Expert Source Melinda Meservy Plant Specialist Expert Interview. 18 August 2020. Purchase concrete pigments online. Concrete pigments come in a variety of colors like blue and red. [9] X Research source If you run out of concrete while filling your mold, mix more. Try to get out all of the lumps from the concrete before pouring it.

steps.title: Pour concrete into the larger box, up to the line that you made.
steps.content: Pour concrete into the larger box, up to the line that you made. Shovel the concrete from the wheelbarrow or bucket into the large container. Continue to fill the larger container until it reaches the mark that you made or is 2 inches (5.1 cm) high. This will form the bottom of your planter. [10] X Research source If you have thicker walls, adjust the pour level of the concrete. For instance, if you marked 4 in (10 cm) from the base of the planter, fill the concrete up to the line that you marked.

steps.title: Place the smaller container in the larger container.
steps.content: Place the smaller container in the larger container. [11] X Expert Source Melinda Meservy Plant Specialist Expert Interview. 18 August 2020. Weigh down the smaller container by filling it with stones or sand. This will prevent the smaller container from floating while you finish filling the mold. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Pour the wet concrete in between the smaller and larger container.
steps.content: Pour the wet concrete in between the smaller and larger container. Slowly pour the concrete in between the containers. Continue pouring the concrete until it completely fills the mold. [13] X Research source The concrete should not fill the small container or connect over the top rim of the small container.

steps.title: Let the mixture cure for a full day.
steps.content: Let the mixture cure for a full day. Set the molds aside in a place where they won’t be disturbed. Cover the top of the molds with a cloth or tarp. Wait a full day so that the concrete can fully harden and set. [14] X Research source Check the instructions on your concrete bag to determine exact curing times.

steps.title: Pull out the smaller mold.
steps.content: Pull out the smaller mold. Grab the edges of the smaller container and pull it out of the concrete. If you covered it with a plastic bag, it should come out fairly easily. Peel away any plastic that may have stuck to the inside of the larger mold. [15] X Research source If you're having trouble getting the small mold out, you can use a crowbar to pry it out of the larger mold.

steps.title: Flip the planter over and lift up the larger container.
steps.content: Flip the planter over and lift up the larger container. If you sprayed the inside with cooking spray, the planter should slide out. If you used a cardboard box, peel away the sides and bottom of the box to reveal the concrete planter. [16] X Research source If you're having trouble getting the planter out, don't be scared to break the larger mold.

steps.title: Decorate the outside of the planter to personalize it.
steps.content: Decorate the outside of the planter to personalize it. You can superglue stones, decorative glass, or beads to the outside of the planter to give it a more colorful look. You can use masonry paint to paint the outside of the planter if you want it to be a different color. [17] X Research source Before you paint the planter with masonry paint, put a coat of block primer on the planter so that you have a flat surface to work on. [18] X Research source You can use stencils to paint specific images onto your planters. Tape the stencil to the side of the planter and fill in the gaps with masonry paint. [19] X Research source

steps.title: Plant your indoor or outdoor plant
steps.content: Plant your indoor or outdoor plant in the planter. Fill the interior of the planter with potting mix and plant whatever flower or houseplant that you want. You may want to amend and replace the soil once a month to keep your plant alive and healthy. [20] X Research source You can also grow a new plant by planting a seed in the pot.
